title: enterprise rent a car announces aberdeen graduate jobs boost
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. title: joinery workshop could become new stonehaven harbour cafe
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. title: drivers cyclists must share space
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. title: coronavirus in scotland here are the key demographics
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. title: aberdeens dean sutherland wins wbc international silver title with stoppage victory
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. title: wbc international silver champion dean sutherland insists his title win could have been stopped earlier
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. title: scotland 15 south africa 30 world champions overpower scots with something to spare at murrayfield
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. title: your pictures november 12 2021
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowIt#s a special photograph this week for our weekly Your Pictures feature.The fantastic image was sent to us by regular contributor Aileen Gillies, now a photographer with a growing reputation and wide range of calendars to her credit.Aileen sent us this photograph of the sunset at Arduaine, taken on Tuesday November . She also mentioned that this was her #birthday sunset#.So, it might be a few days late, but happy birthday Aileen!

title: red star stung late in exciting league match
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.RJD-sponsored Red Star welcomed Baljaffray to the Joint Campus G pitch last Saturday where the sides played out a thrilling three-all draw in a match which swung in either direction in horrendous conditions.The sides exchanged goals in the first half, with Stuart MacLean reacting quickest in the box after the Baljaffray keeper couldn’t hold a Fraser Talbot shot and the striker scored to net his eleventh goal in eight games.Baljaffray forced a succession of corners near the end of the half and were on level terms when Red Star were only able to partially clear a corner which fell to the away side’s full back and his shot via the aid of a deflection went past young Leon Murphy in the Star goal. -Into the second half and Star could have retaken the lead when Aaron Moore latched onto a drilled cross from strike partner Stuart MacLean, however, his effort was blocked by an excellent save from the Baljaffray number one.The visitors took the lead after  minutes when a cross caused confusion in the Star defence and the Baljaffray forward had the simple task of finishing into an empty net from close range.Star huffed and puffed for an equaliser, however, they were frustrated by excellent goalkeeping until the goal came in fortuitous circumstances after a long ball was nodded past his own keeper by the Baljaffray centre back meaning the sides were level with  minutes to go.Star took the lead with five minutes remaining when Aaron Moore was able to burst clear of the Baljaffray backline and finish well into the far corner to make it -.This should have been enough to see Star over the line but Baljaffray scrambled a late equaliser when Star again failed to clear a free kick and the ball was bundled over the line to see the match end -.Lochgilphead Red Star are on their travels on Saturday November  when they face their toughest test of the season so far as they take on league leaders and title favourites Arthurlie.

title: argyllshire advertiser leader column november 12 2021
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowNo matter how frustrating the Covid clerical fiasco has been, there is no excuse for taking it out on vaccination staff at clinics.They have worked beyond the call of duty during the pandemic and continue to be there to help us.Questions, however, must be asked over the management of the Covid booster programme.Senior NHS Highland and HSCP managers must bear responsibility for the needless mistakes, many of which a little local knowledge could have quickly rectied.We detected, in the response to our enquiries, a note of irritation at NHS staff time taken up addressing media questions as the confusion unfolded.The situation is entirely of NHS senior management#s making, and the media has every right to ask questions of a publicly-funded service on behalf of the people of Argyll and Bute.We hope and trust, however, that the admin problems have now been resolved.That aside, thank you to all the NHS staff helping each of us by delivering vital Covid booster jabs # it is genuinely appreciated while the virus remains a threat.And this Sunday at am, let#s think about others who made unimaginable sacrices on our behalf.Lest we forget.

title: boxes of kindness set for eastern europe
story: Updated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowHundreds of people across Argyll have created special Christmas presents for vulnerable people in Eastern Europe.Churches, scout groups and iniduals packed shoeboxes full of gts for children and adults dealing with poverty in Albania, Bulgaria, Hungary, Kosovo, Moldova, Romania, Serbia and Ukraine.Run by the Blythswood Care charity, the shoebox appeal last year saw , presents delivered to struggling communities.A spokesperson for the charity said: #Your kindness and generosity makes such a dference receiving a shoebox brings so much joy#.A Blythswood Care van, staffed by James O’Neill and Gerry Tapley collected shoebox gts in Lochgilphead, Clachan and Tarbert on Thursday November .A steady stream of people dropped off boxes at the Lorne Street car park including representatives from Lochgilphead Baptist Church, the th Argyll Explorer Scouts and Lochgilphead Free Church.

title: galashiels-20mph-speed-limit-set-reversed-roads
story: THE mph speed limit on some Galashiels roads will be removed, a councillor has revealed.Scottish Borders Council introduced the controversial restrictions in October  as part of a trial under its Spaces for People scheme.At a meeting of the community council on Wednesday , Galashiels representative Harry Scott announced that some ldquorevisions are set to go ahead.ldquoTherersquos been some criticism and some love of them [the limits] but the plan at the moment is for a revision, the independent councillor said.:Gala remembers only woman from town to die on active service in WWAccording to Mr Scott, the mph limit will be reinstated ldquoon the road leading to the recycling centre past Melrose Gait and Coopersknowe.A ldquobuffer zone of mph will also be placed from the town boundary on Melrose Road to near the junction with Hawthorn Road, with new mph signage to be erected from that point to indicate the change in limit.Winston Road will also have its mph limit reinstated down to the roundabout with Galafoot, says Mr Scott.He confirmed that the mph limit will stay on Wood Street, as well as on ldquoall the residential schemes in the town.Member of the public Richard Lees said that ldquoa lot of people have universal disapproval of these mph limits on social media, and asked Mr Scottthe council has a way of measuring the advantages of the scheme.:Borders man encouraged young girl to engage in sexual activity, court hearsResponding, Mr Scott said: ldquoIrsquom not an expert but I do knowa child is struck at mph they have got a  per cent more chance of surviving thantheyrsquore struck at mph.ldquoThere have been some concerns about an increase in pollution but Irsquom reliably told that a car travelling at mph in the proper gear exerts less pollution than one travelling at mph.ldquoMy information is that the mph limit is overall a good thing. I do share with you some reservations about whether mph is really a requirement for a lsquothrough roadrsquo in a town but I think what is being proposed by the officer is reasonable and I certainly donrsquot have any objection to it..removeThe mph speed restrictions are part of an -month council trial covering  towns and villages in the Borders.The aim of the scheme is to make it easier for people to safely walk and cycle during everyday journeys.:I know some people wont be happy: Height of Gala Christmas tree revealedChanges to the restrictions were also announced at a meeting of Selkirk Community Council meeting on Monday .On the A into Selkirk from Galashiels the mph is to be reinstated up to Viewfield Park, then mph through the town thereafter.A mph limit on the A from Hawick will also be reinstated ndash however police and road safety officers have yet to decide where.

title: westruther-woman-admits-drink-driving-offence-weekend
story: A BORDERS woman appeared from custody at Jedburgh Sherf Court on Monday and admitted a drink-driving offence at the weekend while already disqualied.Fty-one-year-old Joyce Barrett, of Westruther, also pleaded guilty to having no insurance.Sentence was deferred until next month for the production of background reports and she was released on bail.You might also be interested in:mph speed limit set to be reversed on Galashiels roads, meeting hearsBorders man encouraged young girl to engage in sexual activity, court hearsDog fouling in the Borders is getting worse and worse, says Gala councillor

title: 3-000-half-price-tickets-available-abbotsford-house
story: VISITORS can explore Sir Walter Scotts beautul Scottish Borders home at Abbotsford for half price thanks to a limited offer as part of the Visit Scotlands Great Days Out in Scotland scheme.There are nearly , half-price tickets to claim, and the offer includes entry to the House, Chapel and Gardens.It also includes half price entry to Christmas  in the historic house, which opens on December th.This magical Christmas experience will allow visitors to explore the house as it might have been for Christmas in Scotts day including a special edition Christmas audio guide.Giles Ingram, Abbotsfordrsquos Chief Executive said: ldquoLast year we extended the season for the first time in seven years, and wersquove decided to do the same again in Scottrsquos th anniversary year, making the event even bigger and better!ldquoWersquore delighted that for the first time ever Father Christmas will be on site to meet local children and our Christmas Market will now be over two weekends in November. The historic house will be open for longer, decorated for the celebrations and telling the story of a special festive season for Scott, when he celebrated the completion of his wonderful home.ldquoAlthough  hasnrsquot been as dficult as , we have missed our international and group visits, which were an important part of our income. Thankfully we have continued to welcome visitors from across the UK and our local market has been very supportive, especially helping us to celebrate Scottrsquos th birthday at Scottfest  in August. Wersquore now inviting them to come again and celebrate a very special Christmas with us.The celebrations at Abbotsford begin with a Christmas Market over the last two weekends in November, featuring local crafters and suppliers. The Markets will run from .am ndash pmon Saturday and Sunday, th  st and th  th November. Christmas wreath making workshops are running on Friday th November..removeThe historic house will close as usual on Tuesday November th and then re-open on Saturday th December, beautully decorated with foliage from the estate and with a unique literary inspired Christmas tree in Scottrsquos magnicent Library.Also on Saturday th December, Father Christmas will arrive at Abbotsford for the first time. Local children can meet him and his Elves in his festive grotto every Friday, Saturday and Sunday until th December.A Christmas shopping evening will be held in the Abbotsford gt shop on Thursday nd December where visitors can find unique presents, including a range of exclusive items created to celebrate the th anniversary of Sir Walter Scott, including Abbotsford gin  whisky.Ochiltreersquos cafeacute will also remain open throughout December for visitors to enjoy their Christmas menu and festive treats. The gt shop and cafeacute are open seven days a week, am-pm, until rd December and am-pm on Christmas Eve. They are also open thndash th Dec, am-pm, and st Dec, am-pm.Visitors should check the opening dates and times before visiting.Full details of dates, times and tickets for events are on Abbotsfordrsquos web site: scottsabbotsford

title: coronavirus-scottish-government-shares-borders-case-update
story: THE Borders has recorded  new cases of coronavirusin the last day, latest figures show.According to Scottish Government data published at pm today , the Borders has now seen , cases of the virus since the start of the pandemic.There are  people in the hospital in the Borders with confirmed cases of the virus ndash one fewer than yesterday.Scotland has now recorded , cases of the virus since March last year, according to the latest data.

title: bright-side-life-hailed-huge-success
story: THE BRIGHT Side of Le benefit show which lit up the Eastgate Theatre last month has been hailed a huge success and could potentially become an annual event.Local community drama group Tweed Theatre brought together, over two nights on nd and rd October, a slew of talented local performers to celebrate the resurgence of performing arts.Tweed Theatre itself, along with the Downright Homespun Radio Company, Sara Bolesrsquo Stride Young Dancers and Eastgate Follies, Shakespeare at Traquair and Celtic Beat with Joe Wilton, collaborated in a production lasting a little over an hour which showcased the cream of local talent in a fabulously upbeat celebration of live drama, comedy, music and dance.The eveningrsquos entertainment involved hysterically funny satirical sketches from DHRC, superb dancing from Sara Bolesrsquo young and mature artists, a scintillating  minute Hamlet from Shakespeare at Traquair, two classic excerpts from Tweed Theatre-one from an Alan Bennett monologue and the other Mrs Culfeatherrsquos mince from The Steamie, and all rounded off by Nomad Beatrsquos sensational Celtic Beat grouprsquos foot-tapping music.The finale saw the audience joyfully joining in two verses of the immortal Monty Pythonrsquos Always Look on the Bright Side of Le, the song after which the show was named.The production was so successful, raising a considerable amount for the Eastgate Theatre, sending people home happy on both nights and encouraging local performers to collaborate creatively, that there is a feeling amongst the performers that the iety benefit show could become a regular event. Watch this space!Organisers wish to thank the ferociously talented artists who came together and say that it was worth the six months of planning to see the audience spilling into the street entertained and looking forward to what we all hope will be a completeto enjoying the thrill of live performance.

title: club-international-rugby-fans-oval-ball
story: Itrsquos a diluted card of club rugby for supporters in the Borders this weekend but a few exciting games are still taking place.Tonightthere will be a Borders derby in the Premiership when Jed-Forest host Selkirk.In National League Division One Melrose have an away fixture against the Stirling Wolves.In East League Division One Duns have a home game against Haddington and Hawick Force play Hawick Linden in a friendly at Mansfield Park.Tomorrow Gregor Townsend on-form Scotland side face world champions South Africa at BT Murrayfield.In the National League Division one Biggar travel to face Ayr and in National League Division Three Berwick are away to Strathmore.In East League Three Gala YM host Lasswade.In Reserve League East One Biggar A host Jed-forest A whilst on Reserve League East Two Gala A host Lasswade and Kelso Sharks take on Watsonians at Poynder Park.In the Semi-Junior Borders League Jed Thistle face Hawick Youth, Kelso Harlequins meet Gala Wanderers, Melrose Wasps host Duns Colts, Peebles Colts are at home to Carlisle Colts and Selkirk Youth host Morpeth Colts.On Sunday Kelso Ladies host Broughton.In Edinburgh Scotland Women face Japan at the Dam Health Stadium.Kick off times y so always check before going along to the games.

title: a7-driver-overturned-lorry-taken-bgh-serious-injury
story: THE driver of an overturned lorry has been taken to Borders General Hospital with a ldquoserious injury, say police.Officers say they were called to reports of the vehicle on the A near Crude Hill in the early hours of Friday morning .The driver, in his twenties, was taken to hospital.:mph speed limit set to be reversed on Galashiels roads, meeting hearsThe road has been closed to recover the vehicle, according to police.A Police Scotland spokesperson said: ldquoPolice were called to the A near Crude Hill around .am on Friday,  November, following a report of an overturned artic lorry.ldquoThe driver, in his twenties, was taken to Borders General Hospital with a serious injury.ldquoThe road has been closed to facilitate recovery of the vehicle and officers continue to liaise with the relevant partner agencies.

title: local-primary-school-children-raise-funds-poppy-scotland
story: PUPILS at St. Maryrsquos Primary School in Melrose have paid their own special tribute to former pupils who lost their lives during WW in addition to raising money for the charity Poppy Scotland in its centenary year.All of the children have been busy working in their own little poppy factory from painting sheets and sheets of crimson paper to assembling our poppies.They also researched the  young men who spent their schooldays at St. Maryrsquos and ultimately died in that war and were able to find images of  of them.These images were then inserted into large painted poppies.Head of Art at the school Debbie Wood told us: ldquoIt felt appropriate to send these precious photographs back out into the world for people to see over  years later.ldquoWe do so hope that this sparks further conversation and who knows we might find a little more information regarding these young men. The school can be contacted directlyanyone believes that they might be able to add to our memories.ldquoThe support from local business has been wonderful and we look forward to seeing our poppies hung in windows in time for Remembrance.

title: jim-telfers-contribution-world-rugby-recognised
story: BORDERS rugby legend Jim Telfer is to be inducted into World Rugbyrsquos Hall of Fame .The former Hawick High School and Gala Academy headmaster won  caps for Scotland,  as captain.And he made eight test appearances for the British and Irish Lions, on two tours, in  and .A tenacious back-row forward for Melrose, Telfer has the distinction of being the only Scotland international to have played New Zealand, South Africa and Australia without losing.Following his playing career, he became one of the most revered coaches in the game.He coached the Lions on their  tour to New Zealand, Scotland to the Five Nations Grand Slam in  and, as assistant to Sir Ian McGeechan, to a second Grand Slam in .After a break from coaching, Telfer was invited by McGeechan to become forwards coach on the triumphant Lions tour of South Africa in .Through his technical know-how and stirring motivational speeches, Telfer galvanised a Lions pack written off by the press and they laid the  for a - series victory.Telfer, with the assistance of John Rutherford and Hugh Campbell, was successful again in  as Scotland claimed the last-ever Five Nations title under their management.The six stars were selected by the Hall of Fame committee. This comprises of John Eales, David Hands, Henri Garcia, Pablo Mamone, Rob Cole, Anna Richards and Wayne Smith.Eales, the chair of the committee, said: ldquoThe  inductees for the World Rugby Hall of Fame are representative of all that is good in our game. Each of them have been outstanding players in either sevens or s and they have also been important contributors to rugby, in their own countries and globally, off the field.

title: gala-fairydean-rovers-announce-new-initiative-youngsters
story: Gala Fairydean Rovers Academy players will now be invited to all home first team matches with free entry.The Lowland League Club feel that it is important for the youngsters to see where the GFR pathway leads to.Neil Hastings has also voiced his support and looks forward to seeing all players and coaches down at Netherdale soon.He said: ldquoWhen I first arrived at the club it was clear to see there was  still is a lot of excellent work going on with the youth academy. As someone who has always had an interest in youth development and also someone who has worked at ious clubs with youth players, I understand all the dficulties and challenges along the way.ldquoFirst and foremost, when I arrived at the club I had to concentrate on the st team and this will obviously always be my number one focus. However, I now believe we are moving in the right direction, and I really want to try and create a real family environment at the club.ldquoNothing would make me happier on a Saturday to walk out at pm and see as many of the young GFR family shouting, cheering, and supporting the st team. We have the full pathway now for young players at the club from starting their football journey Up to under s football and then the lowland league side.ldquoI think its important for a young players development that they see where they are aiming to try and play. I have spoken with Davie about a few ideas to try and build a relationship between the First team and the young players as I understand its a two-way street and we cant just ask for them to come along a create an atmosphere. I would love for us to get to a point in a few yearrsquos time where we dont need to ask for ball boys, mascots or for them to attend but to hear that theyre heading to Netherdale for the game with their friends anyway.

title: shona-haslam-scottish-borders-council-leader-step
story: SHONA HASLAM is stepping down as leader of Scottish Borders Council, it has been announced.The Conservative councillor for Tweeddale East was appointed as head of the council in .But she is now set to step away from the role to lead a new think tank ldquothat focuses on how we build a stronger community in Scotland for the future.She will remain an elected member for Tweeddale East until the local government election in May next year.Elected members will choose a new leader at the full council meeting on November .Mrs Haslam said: "It has been an honour and a privilege to serve as council leader over the last four years. We have achieved so much including the Borderlands Inclusive Growth Deal, the launch of South of Scotland Enterprise, destination play parks, and iPads to all of our learners through the award winning Inspire Learning programme.ldquoIt has not been an easy four years either with serious floods in our towns, a fire at Peebles High School and of course COVID-. Our communities have joined forces and pulled together in all of these challenges and to see how this has happened has been one of the best things about this role.ldquoI am not leaving the public sector, or politics, and will be leading a new think tank in Scotland that focuses on how we build a stronger community in Scotland for the future.ldquoI am excited about the future and the opportunities it holds and know that the Scottish Borders is going to continue to grow from strength to strength.Council convener David Parker said: "I would like to thank Shona for her work as leader over the past four years and congratulate her on all she has achieved. She has made an enormous contribution to the Scottish Borders.ldquoThe focus she has placed on mental health and the huge amount of work she carried out on Inspire Learning in our schools are just two of the things I think she deserves great credit for.ldquoAs the first female leader of this council she will have a special place in its history..removeldquoI look forward to welcoming and working with the new leader after the council meeting later this month."

title: a7-closure-borders-buses-suspends-x95-services-rest-day
story: BORDERS Buses has suspended X services between Hawick and Carlisle due to a closure on the A.Police were called to reports of an overturned lorryat around .am today , with officers closing the road to recover the vehicle.And Borders Buses says it has taken the ldquohard decision to stop all remaining X services for the remainder of the day due to the closure.A spokesperson for the travel company said: ldquoWe have been informed that the A closure is expected to remain in place for most of the day.ldquoAs this closure is out with our control, we have taken the hard decision to suspend all remaining X services between Hawick and Carlisle for the remainder of today.:Shona Haslam to step down as leader of Scottish Borders CouncilIt is the companyrsquos intention toto normal tomorrow, but this is ldquoonly an optionthe road reopens.According to Traffic Scotland, the A is now running under temporary traffic lights at Canonbie following the overnight incident.Meanwhile, police have confirmed that a crash took place in Stow last night.There were no injuries, according to officers.A Police Scotland spokesperson said: ldquoWe received a report of a road traffic crash involving a car and a lorry on the A Galashiels Road in Stow around .pm on Thursday, November , .ldquoThere were no injuries reported and vehicle recovery was arranged.

title: borders-recorded-70-coronavirus-cases-last-day
story: THE Borders has recorded  new cases of coronavirusin the last day, latest figures show.According to Scottish Government data published at pm today , the Borders has now seen , cases of the virus since the start of the pandemic.There are  people in the hospital in the Borders with confirmed cases of the virus.An issue with the linkage of testing data to hospital activity data forced NHS Borders to revise its hospital occupancy figures reported between October  and  November, .This issue resulted in the number of patients being undercounted.From October -November  there were between  and  people in hospital in the Borders with confirmed cases of coronavirus.Scotland has now recorded , cases of the virus since March last year, according to the latest data.

title: edinburgh-christmas-market-2021-opening-dates-times
story: Christmas is already on the horizon, bringing with it Edinburghs famous markets after a two-year hiatus.The pandemic may have put a halt to the annual markets last year, but this year they are due back in all their festive glory.Edinburghs markets are famous and see thousands of people flock to Princes Street Gardens to get in on the action.This year will be no dferent, so heres everything you need to know about the Edinburgh Christmas markets ...Edinburgh Christmas market dates and opening timesThere are ious markets across the city, which have slightly dferent dates and opening times.The West Princes Street Gardensmarketwill open on Friday November  and run until Saturday January , operating between the hours of am to pm.The George Street eventwill also open on Friday November  until Saturday January from the hours of am to pm.Meanwhile the East Princes Street Gardensmarketwill open at lunchtime on Saturday November .Where are the dferent Edinburgh Christmasmarkets There are markets in three locations in Edinburgh.The West Princes Street Gardens market is accessible from The Mound, Princes Street and Kings Stables Road.The George Street market will take place just up the road on George Street, while the East Princes Street Gardens market can be accessed from Princes Street and Market Street.Where can I park for the Edinburgh Christmas markets If you are attending the West Princes Street Gardens or East Princes Street Gardens markets, there is pay and display available onFrederick Street, George Street, Hanover Street and Waterloo Place.For the George Street market, pay and display parking is available onCharlotte Square, Frederick Street, George Street and Hanover Street.How  can I travel to the Edinburgh Christmas markets There are plenty of transport options to Edinburgh Christmas markets that dont require a car..removeWaverley train station is located within a -minute walk of all three markets, as is the Edinburgh bus station.What will feature at the Edinburgh Christmas markets AtWest Princes Street Gardens there will be  market stalls,  fairground rides, a bar and the information point and box office.The East Princes Street Gardens will feature  market stalls, the Big Wheel, the Double Carousel, a bar, a box office and information point and toilets.George Street will host an ice rink, three market stalls and a bar.

title: selkirk-invited-take-part-canadian-christmas-festival
story: SOUTERS are once again invited to take part in an international Christmas event with other towns and cities named Selkirk.Last year the town was invited to join the Holiday Alley festival held in the city of Selkirk in Manitoba, Canada, which was forced online due to the coronavirus pandemic.As part of the festival in , Selkirk communities around the world were invited to film themselves singing and dancing to a version of the  Days of Christmas. However, this year those wanting to get involved will be singing and dancing along to Dance in the Street, Again ndash written by Selkirk, Manitoba, artist Brenton Thorvaldson and based on the original song Dancing In The Street by Martha and the Vandellas.Organisers of Holiday Alley have also prepared choreography for Souters to follow or you can create your own moves.All the submitted videos will then be edited together in the lsquoWorldwide Dancing in the Street Videorsquo that will air on Holiday Alley web-TV on Tuesday, November . Anyone wishing to take part in this yearrsquos video, should submit their contributions to the Holiday Alley team by November . Visit: forms.gle NDfzbEshVpsEMJ
