story: East Lothian Councilrsquos Labour administration cabinet this week agreed to make Friday, June , a public holiday for all its employees next year.However, while some local authorities are also making Thursday, June , an official holiday, East Lothian workers will not be automatically given the four-day weekend.The UK Government advised councils to move their official May Bank Holiday to Thursday, June , to create the extended holiday.At a meeting of East Lothian Councilrsquos cabinet this week, members were reminded their workers do not get a May Bank Holiday so it cannot be moved to June.Instead, the Labour administration was told staff would beldquoencouraged to take a dayrsquos annual leave to extend the celebrations.Morag Ferguson, head of corporate support, told cabinet: ldquoAs the council does not recognise a fixed May Bank Holiday now, those staff who wish to use one of their annual leave days for the Thursday will be encouraged to do so and managers will be asked to facilitate this where possible.The cabinet agreed to make Friday, June , an extra public holiday for all staff, including teachers, next year.Councillor Jim Goodfellow urged community councils and area partnerships to take the initiative in planning local parties and celebrations across the county.He said: ldquoThis is an event of signicant importance and I am sure there are iniduals and groups within East Lothian who will wish to organise something to mark this day, perhaps with celebrations or street parties.

title: dunbar-schoolgirl-presents-poppy-poem-great-uncles-memory-towns-legion
story: Kirsten Goughrsquos poignant poem, Irsquove Been The Poppy, attracted national interest last year.Youngsters at Dunbar Primary School were studying the Second World War, in which Kirstenrsquos great uncle Cecil Thomas Dundas died.The -year-old was killed when merchant navy ship SS Jumna ndash on which he was rd officer ndash was shelled by the German heavy cruiser Admiral Hipper on Christmas Day .Ahead of this yearrsquos preparations to mark Remembrance Day, Kirsten and her mum Carol were invited to attend a veteransrsquo breakfast meeting organised by Dunbar Legion Poppy Appeal Team.The group has delivered collection cans and boxes throughout the town for this yearrsquos commemorations.To mark  years of the poppy, Kirsten recited her poem to the gathered veterans.She also presented a framed copy, specially printed on school letterhead, to Dunbar Legion Poppy Appeal team leader Sharon Kaszuba.The story attracted interest from the John OrsquoGroats Journal, as well as the University of Southampton, which has archives on the RRS Discovery .

title: east-lothian-remembrance-events-2021-details-commemorations-around-county
story: Remembrance services were scaled back last year in the face of the coronavirus pandemic.Various restrictions are still in place but services are being held in a number of towns and villages.Provost John McMillan said he was glad some Remembrance events couldthis year.He added: ldquoIt is really important to remember and people remember in their own inidual ways.While most communitiesrsquo events are on Sunday, the occasion will be marked in West Barns on Saturday. Anyone attending should head to the villagersquos war memorial for .am, with the Rev Brian Hilsley, interim moderator and locum at Belhaven Parish Church, giving a brief address at .am. The wreath-laying will then take place and refreshments will be available in West Barns Village Hall.In Haddington on Sunday, St Maryrsquos Parish Church is holding two services. There will be the usual informal all-age service at .am, and at .am an in-person, ecumenical service of Remembrance. Members of the congregations of other churches in the town will join with invited representatives of community groups.A spokesperson for St Maryrsquos said: ldquoBecause our capacity is much reduced, there will be limits on the number of people who can attend in-person. As it was in , the service will be livestreamed.To book a place, text or call   -am or -pm tomorrow .A wreath-laying takes place at the townrsquos war memorial at .am, while wreaths will also be laid in Athelstaneford and at the Ferguson Memorial in Haddington.In North Berwick, St Andrew Blackadder Church hosts a service at .am on Remembrance Sunday. Participating organisations will hold a parade to the church, led by North Berwick Pipe Band, leaving Imperial car park at about .am. After the service, there will be a parade to the war memorial, where the Act of Remembrance and wreath-laying ceremony will take place at about noon.In Dirleton, Remembrance Day will see the rededication of the villagersquos war memorial, which has been restored . The memorial service starts at .am at the monument, led by the Rev David Graham Sir Hew Dalrymple will also give a short address and music will be provided by Lyle Crawford, a senior member of North Berwick Pipe Band.Aberlady will have a short service at the war memorial at am and people are being asked to assemble at .am. There will be representatives from Territorial Army and Marine Commandos, community organisations, church, community councillors and Scouts. There will then be a service in Aberlady Parish Church at .am, taken by visiting minister the Rev John Gordon.Kaye MacAskill, church treasurer, said: ldquoNumbers are still restricted in church, so wersquore not able to have groups of unormed organisations. Itrsquos a small representative group from each of them. Some members of the public will be able to come into church but we canrsquot have a full church this year.In Gullane, there is an lsquoactiversquo Remembrance at the villagersquos war memorial at am on Sunday. Refreshments are available at The Watchman Hotel afterwards.In Dunbar, tea and coffee will be served at Dunbar Royal British Legion from am. The parade of organisations will make its way from High Street to the townrsquos war memorial on Marine Road at .am before a service is held at am. The organisations then make their way back into the town centre.A short service of remembrance will be held at the war memorials beside Athelstaneford Parish Church and Stenton Parish Church at .am on Sunday.At Prestonkirk Parish Church in East Linton, there will be a joint service for all three churches in the parish ndash Stenton, Athelstaneford and Prestonkirk ndash at .am and then at the war memorial at noon.Meanwhile, in Prestonpans, a Remembrance parade will go ahead as normal, with a socially distanced crowd in attendance. The parade marches off from the Legion at .am along Rope Walk to Redburn Road, North Grange Avenue and down West Loan to the war memorial. An upgrade to the square that surrounds the war monument is under way but space will be made to ensure the ceremony can take place.In Cockenzie and Port Seton, a similar parade takes place on Sunday, leaving the Legion at .am and arriving at the village green for .am. The service will be followed by a two-minute silence at am before parading to Cockenzie Old Parish Church. Following a service at the church, the parade willto the Legion, where at about .pm a salute and silence, followed by a lament from the pipe band, will take place.In Longniddry, a church service takes place at Longniddry Parish Church on Sunday at .am.In Tranent, a parade starts from East Lothian Co-operative Bowling Club, down Ormiston Road, High Street, Church Street, Winton Place and High Street to Tranent Parish Church for a service at .am.In Elphinstone, a parade begins at .pm from Elphinstone Minersrsquo Club to Main Street for a gathering at the war memorial, before ing to the minersrsquo club for .pm.In Ormiston, a remembrance service takes place at the village church at .am, while two wreaths will be laid at the side of the building. Following the service, a walk to the memorial will take place where a further two wreaths will be laid.Pencaitlandrsquos church holds a service at .am, followed by the community act of remembrance at the war memorial at noon.In Musselburgh, there will be no official service on Remembrance Sunday at the Mall Fountain but a parade will leave Musselburgh Town Hall at .am to walk to St Michaelrsquos Church, Inveresk, for a service of Remembrance.In Wallyford, a service takes place at St Clementrsquos Church at am. Wreaths will be laid in the church garden at am.

title: section-a1-closed-overnight-repairs
story: Overnight repairs are being carried out on the eastbound carriageway of the road between Abbotsview Junction and East Linton.BEAR Scotland is carrying out the work from pm to am, with the eastbound section of road closed between those times.Traffic will come off the A at the Abbotsview Junction and follow the A before rejoining the A at Thistly Cross Roundabout.The ersion is expected to add about three minutes to the journey.Tommy Deans, BEAR Scotlandrsquos south east network manager, said: ldquoThese repairs will enhance safety for motorists.

title: coastguard-lifeboat-called-kayakers-get-difficulty-off-cockenzie
story: North Berwick and Dunbarrsquos Coastguard teams received a call shortly before noon and were joined by Kinghornrsquos RNLI volunteers.Just prior to the arrival of the RNLI crew at about .pm, it was confirmed that the two kayakers had made it ashore but one kayak was still drting east.A spokesperson for Kinghorn RNLI said: ldquoWhilst personnel from North Berwick Coastguard Rescue Team and Dunbar Coastguard attended to the paddlers, we tried to recover the kayak.ldquoAt this point, it became apparent that two other members of the group had continued to Longniddry and their welfare was unknown.ldquoThe leboat was tasked to check up on them but it was soon confirmed that they were safely ashore.ldquoWe then ed to locate the kayak, which by now had drted east of Port Seton onto rocks.ldquoA crew member went ashore to assist Coastguard personnel recover the delicate kayak, which had sustained damage and had filled with water. It was successfully emptied and taken to the harbour for collection.

title: appointments-now-needed-east-lothians-vaccine-bus-long-queues-cold
story: The bus, launched by East Lothian Health and Social Care Partnershipas a drop-in service last Tuesday, was attended by more than  people in its first four days of service.It provides Covid- boosters and flu jabs for lsquopriority groupsrsquo, including people aged over  and those who are clinically extremely vulnerable.The bus visited Ormiston Medical Practice on the first two days and Gullane Medical Practice on Thursday and Friday.Photos shared on social media of the bus at its stop in Gullane showed traffic chaos, forcing the police to attend, and some members of the public complained of waits of up to two hours in the cold.A spokesperson for ELHSCP said: ldquoDue to an extremely high level of interest in the service which resulted in long queues, y waiting times and local traffic disruption, ELHSCP has decided to review how the bus operates.ELHSCP will now deliver an outreach programme and the vaccination bus will operate on an appointment referral basis only. Vaccinations will no longer be available on a drop-in basis.The spokesperson added: ldquoOur expectation is that the majority of people living in East Lothian who are eligible will receive their flu and Covid booster vaccinations at one of our clinics in Musselburgh Primary Care Centre or East Lothian Community Hospital in Haddington.ldquoPlease be assured thatyou are over  or clinically extremely vulnerable and have already received your flu vaccination but are now eligible for your Covid booster, you should expect to receive an appointment letter from NHS Lothian in the coming weeks.Members of the public complained on social media of long waits in the cold.One said: ldquoI waited for about one hour and  minutes for my vaccination.ldquoDespite the pressure of numbers, the staff were very efficient and friendly.Another said: ldquoPersonally feel that this could be done in a much safer environment like a golf course or open field away from homes.ldquoRight now, many people who are potentially sick could be spreading the virus [unknowingly] among vulnerable people.Another added: ldquoPeople were standing out in the icy cold wind for hours today, then they sat under a temporary cover attached to the side of the bus to be injected, then sat on chairs in the cold windy shade until they were allowed to leave.The ELHSCP spokesperson said: ldquoIf you are invited to attend an appointment on the vaccination bus, please be aware that:

title: films-screened-tranents-fraser-centre-weekend
story: The trio star in The Last Duel, which focuses on respected knight Jean de Carrouges.When the much-admired squire Jacques Le Gris viciously assaults Carrougesrsquo we, she steps forward to accuse her attacker, an act of bravery and defiance that puts her le in jeopardy.The film, directed by Ridley Scott, is shown at pm with a second screening at the Tranent venue next Thursdayat pm.Meanwhile, therersquos also plenty to entertain youngsters.The Gruffalorsquos Child takes to the big screen todayand Ronrsquos Gone Wrong is shown on Saturday.The Gruffalorsquos Child sees Gruffalorsquos daughter embark on a journey to find the Big Bad Mouse.Ronrsquos Gone Wrong is the story of Barney, a socially awkward middle-schooler, and Ron, his new walking, talking, digitally connected device, which is supposed to be his lsquoBest Friend out of the Boxrsquo.Both films are shown at pm.

title: youngsters-enjoy-spooky-halloween-party-haddington
story: A group of friends who meet in Haddingtonrsquos Costa decided to put on a party for youngsters in the townrsquos bowling club.One of the members of the group said: ldquoWe decided after the past  months or so wersquod put on a wee party for the kids in the group, as all kids had been doing really great throughout lockdown.ldquoIt was the first party we have held, and hopefully next year we might do a ticket event, and raise funds for charity.ldquoWe all had a fantastic time, it was enjoyed by everyone.Prizes were awarded to spookiest, cutest and best costumes.

title: east-lothian-peeps-past-november-8-12-1996-1971-1921
story: lsquoRESIDENTS flee storm terrorrsquo was the front page of the East Lothian Courier on November , .Hurricane-force winds brought chaos to East Lothian on Wednesday when nearly  people were evacuated after a roof was blown from flats at Prestonpans, some schools had to close, roads were blocked by falling trees and many homes were left without electricity.Weathermen recorded gusts of up to  miles per hour battering the area... the highest wind speeds recorded for almost  years.Some terried residents of the three-storey flats at Middleshot Square, Prestonpans, fled as the roof began to rip off over their heads at around am, many still clad only in their nightwear.But amazingly others slept through the drama and only realised the danger when police and firemen hammered on their doors to evacuate the building.The back door had to be used, as the main entrance was blocked by giant roof sections.WHILEa community joined together to help a youngster.A -year-old Kenyan boy arrived in Haddington for an operation which could help change his le... thanks to a big fundraising effort by townsfolk.For they collected the pound, needed to bring Onesimus Mulwa to Scotland for surgery to have a huge disfiguring cyst removed from the side of his face.The connection with Haddington came about through Onesimusrsquos uncle, Ben Nzidka, who studied at Myreside School of Furniture Restoration at Gford.lsquoYODELLING cobblerrsquo was a headline in The Haddingtonshire Courier on November , .One of the more unusual acts on Hughie Greenrsquos ldquoOpportunity Knocks programme in recent years was that of a yodelling cobbler and his dancing shoes.The exponent of this act, Bill Gore, paid a visit to the Musselburgh Legion Club on Monday and gave an extended programme which illustrated why his performance justied the praise which it received.Supporting the artiste were the members of the resident Bon Accord Band, Allan Law , John Knoxand Ian Imrie.MAIL for residents of East Lothian was badly damaged, reported The Haddingtonshire Courier on November , .On Friday, an unaccountable accident took place in connection with the mail apparatus here, which receives the English bags by the London early morning train.The bags were much damaged and many of the letters were mutilated to such an extent as to make the establishment of the identity impossible.

title: new-magnet-fishing-group-set-musselburgh
story: James Pearson, , of Kilwinning Terrace, has formed Magnet Fishing Musselburgh and hopes to remove anything he sees that will cause harm to local wildle on the River Esk, such as shopping trolleys, bikes, scooters and other metal debris.ldquoIrsquove also retrieved a ladyrsquos purse which was handed into the police, he said.Mr Pearson, a former pupil of Musselburgh Burgh Primary School and Musselburgh Grammar School, has been magnet fishing for about three years after watching the YouTube channel lsquoWW Wendalrsquo.ldquoI thought I would give it a try. I mainly fished by myself on the canals in Edinburgh, he explained.He then made contact with Magnet Fishing Edinburgh and, along with friends, created official Magnet Fishing Scotland, which, he said, was the only group worldwide to be legally allowed to magnet fish the Scottish canal system.Mr Pearson, a hire desk controller for a plant hire company, said: ldquoMagnet fishing has given me so many great friends and surprising finds, I thought I would create a group for my home town.ldquoI see this as giving something back to our brilliant community andit gets a few people out and into the fresh air then thatrsquos a bonus.He explained: ldquoMagnet fishing is tying a high-powered magnet onto a rope and throwing it into a body of water to remove any metallic items.ldquoItrsquos relatively inexpensive magnets range from pound to pound. Anyone can join in. You only need to get a magnet. You fish from the bank ndash I never advise going into the water. You donrsquot know the undercurrent of the water.ldquoI fish as much as I can but usually the weekends. I travel all over Britain magnet fishing.ldquoMy most unusual find was a hand gun I retrieved from the canal system in Glasgow.He added: ldquoMost of my finds are sent to the scrap-yard.Access the Magnet Fishing Musselburgh Facebook at facebook groups

title: tims-tales-learned-mozart
story: The tune had been a favourite of my father, who was very musically gted he played almost anything and everything from banjo and guitar to piano and organ. But his musical taste was very dferent to mine, although I did once manage to get him to sing along to Block Buster by the Sweet.My father died in August , just a week before I started high school at Preston Lodge. Irsquod just turned  years old. Soon afterwards, I remember going into his study, which had previously been out of bounds, and sitting in his chair, surrounded by his books, writing materials and music tapes.These were the days when combined radio and tape recorders were popular. His music tapes were in a special box, all titled in his handwriting. Hersquod recorded the music from the radio so the quality wasnrsquot brilliant.There were moments on the tapes when hersquod not switched it off quickly enough, so hersquod caught snippets of the presenter talking, and sometimes the tape had run out before the tune ended.But all this just made the tape collection a more powerful personal connection to my dad who Irsquod recently lost. So, while he had been unable to interest me in classical music while he was alive, I began to listen to his collection after his death. I would recognise tunes and was now able to put a name to them thanks to the titles hersquod written on the tapes.They conjured up memories for me. One was of a rainy Saturday afternoon in which my father invited me to join him in being the conductor for a Mozart tune. So he showed me how to conduct, leading and living the music with our arm movements. We had fun together doing this for what seemed like an hour or so in our small kitchen, as he explained the dferent instruments involved and how they merge together, and the role of the conductor. It was, in truth, a rare moment, but perhaps thatrsquos why I remembered it so vividly.It was the same Mozart tune that played on my car radio last week. It conjured another memory: of me standing in the kitchen being the conductor to the tune, alone, in the weeks after my fatherrsquos death. Irsquod found the tape and recognised the tune. I then learnt every pause, listened to the instruments and conducted to the music as my father had taught me.I didnrsquot understand it at the time, nobody spoke to me about it, but I now realise that I was in deep grief.My conducting the music was an expression of my loss, but I had nobody to talk to about it or process it I couldnrsquot allow the emotions to surface: ldquoBe strong, now you are the man of the family, boys donrsquot cry, they get on with it.My mother was stunned and closed down as well. I somehow learnt that tears, crying and being upset was something to avoid. So I buried my grief.So I did as advised, I got on with it. Irsquove done OK, I think, for I suppose when we walk with a stone in our shoe long enough we get used to it, and after a while stop noticing it. But, of course, it is still there, and only when we take our shoe off and finally find a way to remove the stone do we feel the dference and understand the effect itrsquos had on our walking.Last week was that moment for me: sitting in my car, overwhelmed with emotion from  years ago, remembering myself as a -year-old boy who felt he was unable to talk about what was then the greatest loss in his le.Irsquom a father myself now, of course, and thank goodness times have changed.There is a greater recognition these days of the need to talk, to express emotions and process feelings that our mental health is as important as our physical health, although words are often not matched with resources.But within our families also, we all need safe spaces to feel upset, let emotions surface and receive support from love ones. And that includes recognising our own mental health needs.I know most of us already know the importance of this. I certainly know it, yet despite this, I still tend to ignore the signs Irsquom struggling until my mental health is in tatters, which helps nobody.Just now my kids are having their own challenges, as so many are, and my own emotions have surfaced in my attempts to give support. The temptation was to quickly re-bury my emotions so I could concentrate on giving that support and also not let anyone down that voice is still in my head: ldquoGet on with it, man up.But that Mozart tune stopped me doing this. It made me connect with how I felt. It helped me understand why the adults close to me, when I was that -year-old boy, didnrsquot ask me how I was feeling or give me space and time to talk about my emotions and express my loss they couldnrsquot because they hadnrsquot allowed it for themselves.Mozart that day gave me the gt of self-care, which has helped me be more effective in caring and supporting loved ones, and ing at well at work.Itrsquos never easy to write about a personal vulnerability there is still that fear of ridicule. I had actually planned to write a historical tale this week, but events, and emotions, took over. There is always next time.Remembrance Day is this week, a time when we collectively pause to remember people we have lost in wars. Veterans know all about long-lasting trauma and loss, and the importance of acknowledging unseen emotional wounds.These issues can affect us all in dferent ways at dferent times. We rarely know the struggles that others are experiencing. Being kind to others includes being kind to yourself.

title: dozen-east-lothian-public-loos-temporarily-closing
story: The busiest public toilets, says East Lothian Council, will stay fully open, though  others will shut.Eight others will be limited to use of the disabled toilet only ndash which can be used by all.Tom Reid, the local authoritys head of infrastructure, said: ldquoWe continue to face extreme challenges due to a combination of staff absence ndash much of it Covid-related ndash as well as a high number of vacancies within our facilities management team.ldquoWe need to ensure our limited cleaning resources at this time are focused on keeping facilities such as schools clean, safe and fully open.ldquoWe appreciate this will be inconvenient and frustrating and we are grateful to communities for their patience and understanding at this dficult time.ldquoThe situation will be kept under review so that we can look to re-open facilities for the benefit of the public when it is practical.Toilets temporarily closing are:The toilets at Musselburgh Links remain closed as a result of fire damage.Locations where only disabled toilets will remain open for everyone to use daily are:Longniddry Bents car park No.SkaterawPort SetonMusselburgh, Fisherrow HarbourYellowcraigJohn Muir Country ParkDunbar, Shore RoadPrestonpansToilets remaining fully open seven days per weekare:

title: put-christmas-tree
story: The date for putting up the Christmas tree tends to y from family to family, with some opting for an early start to the festivities, while others wait right until the last minute.But did you know theres a traditional date for putting up your tree Heres everything you need to know about when you should be putting up your Christmas tree...According to tradition in the UK, you should put your Christmas tree up around the beginning of advent, which is four Sundays before Christmas.This year, advent will start on November , however lots of people will choose to wait until December .Roman Catholic tradition on the other hand is at the other end of the spectrum - waiting until Christmas eve to put up the tree.The Queen finishes "dressing" her tree on Christmas eve, with all the members of the Royal family joining in as a festive family activity.While there are dferent traditions, it is of course completely up to you when you choose to put up your tree and start celebrating the festive season!Again, according to tradition, you should take your tree down on the th day of Christmas, which is January .The first day of Christmas is unsurprisinglyDecember  and traditionally is followed by  further days of celebration.January  marks the beginning of the Christian holiday Epiphany.Superstition suggests it is "bad luck" to keep your decorationsup after this date.However last year many people around the country kept their Christmas lights up well into February to maintain some festive cheer during the post-Christmaslockdown.

title: scotland-v-moldova-channel-kick-off-time-watch-live-tv-tonight
story: Steve Clarkes side currently sit in second place with  points trailing Denmarkwho lead with  points.The top two teams from each group will qualy for the play-offs for the  Quatar World Cup anda win tonight will secure Scotlands second place finish.The pressure may be on, but Scotland can come into the match with confidence having won - against Moldova in September.Of course, that match was slightly closer than anticipated and took place in front of a home crowd whereas tonights match is at Zimbru stadium in Moldova.Regardless, Scotland will look to close the deal to take them once step closer to the World Cup dream.Heres what you need to know about tonights match and how you can tune in...Kick-off for Scotland v Moldova is at pm on Friday November .The match will take place at Zimbru stadium in Moldova, which is around a  hour flight from Scotland.The match will be broadcast live on Sky Sports, with subscribers able to stream the match throughthe Sky Go app.People who are not Sky customers can watch via NOWTV by buying a day pass for pound..Steve Clarke has named a -player strong squad for the World Cup Qualiers.Goalkeepers:Craig Gordon , Jon McLaughlin , Liam Kelly .Defenders:Stephen ODonnell , Nathan Patterson , Jack Hendry , Grant Hanley , Scott McKenna , Liam Cooper ,Kieran Tierney , Andy Robertson .Midfielders:Billy Gilmour , Kenny McLean , Callum McGregor , Stuart Armstrong Stev, David Turnbull , John McGinn , Lewis Ferguson , Scott McTominay .Strikers:Lyndon Dykes , Che Adams , Ryan Christie , Ryan Fraser , Kevin Nisbet .The starting line-up will be announced before the match later today.

title: scotland-v-denmark-kick-off-time-channel-watch-world-cup-qualifier
story: As it stands, Denmark leads Group F with  points while Scotland is in second place with ,  points ahead of Israel.Steve Clarkes side will play Moldova on Friday evening, and a win will mean they guarantee their qualication for the play-offs next year.If they can secure victory over Moldova, it will take the pressure off Scotland for their match against Denmark, who have gone unbeaten so far in the tournament.The top two teams in each group will progress tothe next stage of qualication, with the play-offs taking place in March .With full capacity crowds set toto Hampden Park on Monday night, heres what you need to know about Scotland v Denmark...Scotland will play Denmark at :pm on Monday November .The match will take place at Hampden Park, Glasgow, making it another home game for Scotland.The match will be broadcast live on Sky Sports, with subscribers able to stream the match throughthe Sky Go app.People who are not Sky customers can watch via NOWTV by buying a day pass for pound..Group F as it stands:Denmark:  pointsScotland:  pointsIsrael:  pointsAustria:  pointsFaroe Islands:  pointsMoldova:  pointThe play-offs will take place on March  and  .The World Cup in Quatar will start on Monday November  , taking place later in the year than usual due to the high summer temperatures in Doha.

title: scotland-v-south-africa-tv-channel-kick-off-scotland-rugby-match
story: Last week the team played against Australiain front of a home crowd, winning -in a close and dramatic match.Now turning their attention to South Africa, the odds looktipped in the latters favour, with the team having won the last six head-to-heads.However, Scotland comes off the back of two triumphs and with a home crowd behind them once again, the team will look to extend their successful run.South Africa arrive in Edinburgh following their -win over Wales last week, so regardless of the final outcome of Saturdays match,it looks set to beexciting.As rugby enthusiasts once again fill up the Edinburgh stadium, heres how you can watch at home...The Scotland v South Africa match will take place at Murrayfield on Saturday November at pm.It is Scotlands third game in the autumn series, which will take place throughout November.Amazon Prime hasthe broadcast rights for the autumn international series in the UK.You will need a membership to tune in, butyou dont already have one you can sign up to a -day free trial.If you dont want to continue your trial after the -days however, you will need to remember to cancel your subscription.Here is Scotlands schedule for the autumn series:Scotland v South Africa: Saturday November  at pmScotland v Japan: Saturday November  at pmThe Scotland team for Saturdays match is yet to be confirmed.Meanwhile, this was the line-up for last weeks match against Australia:Stuart HoggDarcy Graham, Chris Harris, Sam Johnson, Duhan van der Merwe Finn Russell, Ali Price Pierre Schoeman, George Turner, Zander Fagerson, Sam Skinner, Grant Gilchrist, Jamie Ritchie, Hamish Watson, Matt Fagerson.Replacements:Ewan Ashman, Jamie Bhatti, Oli Kebble, Jamie Hodgson, Josh Bayliss, George Horne, Adam Hastings, Kyle Steyn.

title: send-letters-santa-royal-mail-year--
story: Theres no need to try and sendletters up the chimney, just pop it in a post box instead.For -years, Royal Mail has been helping hundreds of thousands of children post their letters to Santa.Heres how you can send Santa letters this year...You can send your letters to Santa this year at the address:Santa Father Christmas,Santarsquos Grotto,Reindeerland,XM HQLetters should be sent by Friday December  to ensure time for response.Make sure to attachfull name and address so senders can receive a reply from Santa.The card from Santa will include a special note from the man himself and a recipe for a gingerbread Buddy the elf recipe.If you cant wait for the response, the card can be downloaded from the Royal Mail website.Royal Mail is encouraging customers to shop early and post early for Christmas this year.Its latest recommended posting dates for mail to arrive in time for Christmas are:Saturday  DecemberTuesday  DecemberThursday  December

title: covid-scotland-need-passenger-locator-form-return-uk
story: Before arriving in the UK, travellers must complete a form detailing where they have been and where they are travelling to.This applies to everyone coming to the UK from abroad, evenyou are only transiting through the country.Heres everything you need to know about filling in the form and travelling to the UK from abroad...You must complete a passenger locator form within-hours before travelling to the UK.Yoursquoll need to show thisform when you check in to travel or board your plane, train or ferry to the UK.If you have not filled out the form, you could be denied travel.The form asks for details of where you have been, vaccination status and where you are going.To complete the form yoursquoll need:You can fill out your passenger locator form here.England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland are following a four nationsapproach to international travel, meaning the rules for all four countries are the same.If you are fully vaccinatedyou are still required to take a test within two days of arrival in the UK, however this can now be a lateral flow test instead of a PCR test as previously required.Lateral flow tests are cheaper than PCR tests.If you are not fully vaccinated, you must take a test before travelling to the UK, book and pay for tests for day and day  after arrival and quarantine for  days.You will also be required to complete a passenger locator form.

title: runs-scotland-investigation-scotlands-corridors-power-full
story: Our subscribers will get exclusive access to the people and organisationswith signicant influence over so many aspects of our lives.From the hundreds of secret lobbying meetings to who really runs Scotlands wind farms, whisky and media - the investigation will leave no stone unturned in a bid to stimulate discussion and debate.Here, you can find every article published in the week-long investigation so far - with this piece being updated daily with new exclusive stories.To make sure you do not miss out on the high-quality insight, join us today by taking out a subscription for just pound for two months here.Hundreds of meetings between Scottish ministers and multinationals, wealthy iniduals and other influentialorganisationswere left off the lobbying register in  due to loopholes in legislation, The Ferret can reveal.Analysis of Scottish Government ministersrsquoengagements in shows that meetings, potentially of key public interest, were not in the register, including those between ministers andcompaniesawarded multi-million poundUK and Scottish contracts to supply the NHS in the run-up to Covid-.Read the full scale of unrecorded discussions here.Professional lobbyists, including former politicians, advisors and a former minister have met with Scottish Government representatives on behalf of clients  times since March , The Ferret can reveal.Scotlandis home to dozens of public relations, think-tanks and consultancy firms, including several formed by or employing people who served in the upper echelons of government.Find out the whos who of professional lobbyists here.Questions have been raised over the power and influence of energycompaniesfollowing analysis by The Ferret revealing how key sectors dominate Scottish lobbying.The Ferretcategorisedorganisationsthat lobbied Scottish Government ministers since the register was introduced in  to increase transparency.Read the full exclusive analysis here.Bigbusinessincluding oil and renewable energy, farming, fishing, finance and whisky dominated Scotland Office ministersrsquo meetings last year, analysis by The Ferret has found.We looked at all external meetings logged in  by Alister Jack, Secretary of State forScotland, UK Government ministers for Scotland David Duguid and Iain Stewart, as well as Scottish Tory leader Douglas Ross, who was deputy Secretary of State until he resigned in May that year.Read the full report exclusively here.The number ofcompaniesregistered in tax havens investing in Scotland over the last decade has increased by nearly  per cent.Analysis of Scottish Governmentdataby The Ferret found that in  there were  firms registered in the Cayman Islands, Bermuda and British Virgin Islands operating, compared to  in . Their collective turnover last year amounted to just over poundbn.Read the full exclusive story here.Nearly a third of Scotlandrsquos biggest wind farms have owners with links to offshore tax havens in the Cayman Islands, Luxembourg, Guernsey and Jersey.An investigation by The Ferret has also revealed that  of the largest  wind farms are ultimately ownedoutwithScotland in England, Spain, France, Germany, Norway, China and where.Read the full report here.Nearly  per cent of malt whisky distilleries are ultimately owned bycompaniesoutside Scotland with wealthy people linked to the industry including a French fashion billionaire, an Australian yoghurt tycoon, a Swiss philanthropist and Thailandrsquos richest man.The Ferret can reveal that of the Scots distilleries only a thirdare owned by Scottish firms.Read the full story here.Ten of Scotlands major newspapers are owned by just three men: Rupert Murdoch, Lord Rothermere and Frederick Barclay. They are all billionaires who, personally or through their businesses, have used thelawto avoid paying tax.An analysis by The Ferret reveals that all but one of Scotlands national newspapers, the Sunday Post, are owned in other countries.Read the full storyhereFive privatecompanieswho employ around three quarters of the workforce in Scotlandrsquos arms industry had thousands ofclosed doormeetings with the UK Government between  and .As part of TheFerretrsquosWho Runs Scotlandinvestigation we looked at firmsoperating in Scotlandrsquosdefenceindustry and examined data about them obtained by the Campaign Against Arms Trade .Read the full report here.The chief executives of quangos appointed by Scottish Government ministers were paid over poundm in total last year, leading to ldquoexcessive pay gaps between those at the top and lower paid public sector workers, The Ferret has found.In the course of ourresearchwe looked at the salaries ndash before bonuses or pension tops-up ndash of  leaders of quangos . There are just over  quangos in Scotland, which include Scottish governmentpublic andhealthbodies, executive agencies, non-ministerial offices and commissions.Read the full exclusive story here.Women board members appointed to Scotlandrsquos public bodies get paid half a million pounds less than their male counterparts, despite a drive for gender equality, The Ferret can reveal.Published pay arrangements for board members across  dferent public bodies, where appointments are largely overseen by the Scottish Government, show there are now virtually equal numbers of men and women serving on them.Read the full story here.Influential bankers,retired senior civil servants, well-connected industry insiders, powerful chief executives and former politicians - meet Scotlandrsquos quango class, the people who serve on the boards of Scotlandrsquos public bodies.Some roles are unpaid, and manyworkextra hours intheirdevotion to public service. But analysis by The Ferret of Scottish Government public board positionshas also found a web of influential connections binding many serving in the public sector.Read the full analysis here.So who runs Scotland  Thatrsquos been the central question of The Ferret and The Heraldrsquos week-long investigation.Along the way wersquove examined the corridors of power and looked at who gets the most access to ministers ndash and who doesnrsquot.Find out the top most influential people in Scotland here.Scotlandrsquos biggest private landowner has been attacked as ldquomanipulative and ldquoundemocratic after The Ferret revealed that his company lobbied the Scottish Government to stymie plans for a spaceport in Sutherland.A letter released under freedom of informationlawshows thatWildland Limitedmdash which runs three large estates acrossScotlandfor Danish billionaire,Anders Holch Povlsenmdash warned the former ruraleconomyminister, Fergus Ewing, that its planned investments could be endangered by the spaceport.Read the full story here.Scotlandneeds a radical sht in the way that power and influence are distributed to help address democratic deficits and rebuild trust in the political process, The Ferret has been told.Politicians and campaigners reacting to our week-long investigation ndash Who Runs Scotland ndash claimed it has revealed deep flaws in our transparency legislation and a heavy reliance on big businesses based outwith Scotland, including those with links to tax havens.Read the full final story here.

title: scottish-politics-features-covid-sign-newsletters
story: Weve been expanding our newsletter service here at The Herald, and we want to take you through our new and improved offerings.You can subscribe to our newslettersyoure a registered user or a subscriber by heading to our sign up page and selecting your favourites.Every day, were giving you a rundown of who you can expect in our incredible Voices section.We go through the columnists of the day, giving a sneak peek into their musings - and well also showcase the fantastic illustrations from our in-house artist, Steven Camley, as well.In April, we launched a new evening political newsletter, Unspun, which promises readers an exclusive analysis of the day in Scottish politics - and a look at whats coming next.As Scotland deals with the aftermath of what was one of the most important Scottish elections in history, were bringing you top insight from some of our most popular contributors every weekday at pm.Wersquove enlisted the help of Alison Rowat on Tuesdays, Kevin McKenna on Wednesdays, Iain Macwhirter on Thursdays and Neil Mackay on Fridays.For all the latest coronavirus news in Scotland, including the latest figures and updates, make sure you subscribe to our Covid in Scotland newsletter, reaching inboxes at pm each day.Youll be given the latest figures in Scotland, and have all the latest news and analysis about the pandemic from our health correspondents at your fingertips.At pm, well take you through the stories our readers have been enjoying the most from that day.Well give you a rundown of the headlines and a preview of the pieces that have been getting our readers talking in our catch-up newsletter - perfect for your commute home.In addition to politics, fans of Scotlands arts and cultural scene are set to benefit from our brand new Herald Magazine newsletter, reaching inboxes every Saturday at pm.Written by assistant editor Garry Scott and senior features writer Susan Swarbrick, youll get the latest from our weekly Saturday magazine straight to your inbox, and our top picks from the pages.So sit back, relax, and get the latest straight to your inbox everyday by signing up here

title: green-scotland-can-read-investigation
story: From big-name polluters to Scotlandrsquos most deteriorating rivers and lochs, The Heraldrsquos exclusive, week-long investigation kicks off on Tuesday, October , to answer some of the crucial questions in the ongoing climate crisis.Hot off the back of the successfullsquoWho Runs Scotland rsquo series in July, no stone will be left unturned in The Herald and The Ferretrsquos joint bid to uncover wrongdoing, stimulate debate, and generate discussion.This special series will run in print and online all of this week, exclusively to our subscribers.To make sure you do not miss out on the high-quality insight, join us today.

title: callum-easter-making-music-making-living
story: ldquoIrsquom OK, he says eventually. ldquoIrsquom a lot better than I have been recently. Because Irsquove been really stressed out.Friday morning in Leith and Easter has a new album, entitled System, to promote. We are sitting at a table outside the Word of Mouth Bistro to talk, but Easter seems a little edgy, a little haunted even. He sits at an angle, a little hunched up, maybe uncomfortable with talking about himself, maybe uncomfortable full stop.Easter is a singer songwriter who grew up in Dunbar and now lives in Leith. He is  and he and has just made a ferocious and fun record. System is a lo-fi, full-flavour thing saturated in pop melodies and dirty distortion and filled to the brim with short, sharp songs that carry echoes of early rockrsquonrsquoroll and Glam-era T-Rex, built around a voice thatrsquos gravelly croon. The result is genuinely thrilling.Easter will take the compliment, but the truth is, he seems a little weighed under today. ldquoItrsquos a bit strange. It was supposed to come out August initially and then September and now November. So, Irsquom kind of over it already, he says of the album. ldquoI wish it had come out earlier.Why so  Because itrsquos already November, he says. ldquoThen itrsquos Christmas and then itrsquos  and then everyonersquos looking for the new thing.Therersquos a wary, weary air to him today. Hersquos been struggling with things of late, he admits mostly about how to make music and how to make money at the same time.ldquoI donrsquot knowI should really be saying this, but you do consider packing it all in, he tells me at one point. ldquoJust the amount of time you put in, the hours for something to just go up and then ...He pauses, changes direction, something he does a lot during our short time together. ldquoThe level Irsquom at gigging is not covering the bills. Thatrsquos why I do solo, so I can kind of bring a bit home. But the amount of time hellip Yeah, itrsquos a tricky balance.I hope he feels it is worth it because System, his second album is a sticky, febrile compulsion, easily one of my favourite albums of the year. A pop album with a dark heart.ldquoI wanted to make a party album, he says, ldquobut then, lyrically, itrsquos maybe a party at the end of the world or something.It is mostly all his own work. Twin sisters Pauline and Jacqui Cuff, aka The Leith Congregational Choir, aka Soho, fondly recalled for their Smiths-sampling  hit Hippychick, contribute to the album from their home in Birmingham .Otherwise, he made the album himself in his tiny Leith studio just a few streets away from where we sit now. ldquoItrsquos all me playing, Easter points out.And much of what we hear are single takes, ldquoso you can feel the energy, he adds.ldquoMaybe I double track the guitar, but yoursquore just trying to bottle it basically. Production-wise, therersquos a lot of distortion going on everything. Vocals as well.The sound was inspired by listening to early Bo Diddley demos and Jessie Mae Hemphill. ldquoI discovered her this year. Shersquos from Mississippi. She used to play with her family in a fe and drum band and therersquos a live recording of her songs and you can hear that in there. I love that. I wish I could roll a snare. Thatrsquos what Irsquom working on.When he starts talking about music you can hear his enthusiasm audibly rise. From these influences he has created a raw, punchy, aggressive sound sweetened by his ear for melody. The noise of it is in keeping with the lyrics which often come from a dark place, whether itrsquos his horror at politiciansand just general morbidities.The first song What You Think  ndash which is, by the way, a total banger ndash basically begins with you imagining you are dead, Callum, I point out.ldquoThat, I guess, is trying to grab peoplersquos attention with that first line. During the pandemic to start the album with that line hellip I did think about it hellipldquoI didnrsquot have anything .He raises his head. ldquoThatrsquos a positive song as far as just living, basically.When yoursquore writing songs, Easter adds, yoursquore reacting to whatrsquos going on around you. ldquoAnd itrsquos been a very tense time. So much information and anxiety. So that kind of comes across. And trying to balance that in the lyrics hellip Not trying to be ambiguous but hellip He pauses again, questions himself. ldquoIs there much ambiguity in there He doesnrsquot have an answer. ldquoI was just trying to lay it out as I see it.Whatrsquos clear is that whatever has him on edge today itrsquos not all personal. ldquoIrsquove stopped watching the news really which hellip I dunno hellip Maybe I should start watching it again. But you just get so bogged down with everything.He s to the title track. ldquoThat song is about whatrsquos important around you. Because how do you change things  What needs to be fixed  Is it the billionaires  Are there too many billionaires Hersquos clearly not one of them. To keep making music he has a iety of day jobs, often working up to  hours a week.ldquoI usually have about three things on the go outside the music moneywise and that kind of lets me stay on my toes and be a bit flexible. But itrsquos a tricky balance.These jobs y from manual labour to sound design. ldquoWith the pandemic all my freelance work went, he says.The music, though, Callum, yoursquore going to keep on doing it ldquoYeah. I will. I had a wee rocky spell. I love recording and making the music, but thatrsquos about  or  per cent of it.ldquoSince the restrictions have been lted, Irsquove probably done about four or five gigs and theyrsquove all been dferent set-ups so I need to settle on that a bit. But part of me quite likes mixing it up like that. I like it when therersquos a feeling that the audience know that I donrsquot know whatrsquos going to happen and riding that thatrsquos a buzz.ldquoItrsquos how to make it more profitable.What, I ask him, is the shape of le outside music  ldquoI think thatrsquos whatrsquos been problematic for my mental health, really. I just need nothing for a bit at some point because all the gaps are filled up with music. Irsquove got family, yeah, two kids, no motor. what the f*** am I doing, really  Itrsquos been tense, man.This is the point where idealism meets reality, I guess. Irsquom hoping when it comes to Easter the idealism wins out. The album is a legacy, I suggest. I hope he feels thatrsquos worthwhile.ldquoYeah, sometimes I do.Given everything wersquove talked about this might seem a ridiculous question but what are his ambitions for his music  ldquoItrsquos got to be from here. He beats a fist against his heart. ldquoAndI can make a living just doing that, thatrsquos it. I donrsquot want to be a celebrity. Nah. That kind of veneer therersquos too much of that.And yet, as a new short film he has made shows, he has real presence, which, admittedly, is a dferent thing. The short plays out like an alternative vision of those Saturday night light entertainment shows from the s and s, in this case, ldquo minutes of dancers, a kne thrower, a dominatrix, he explains. ldquoAnd me singing. The self-loathing comes across. Itrsquos a bit dark. Itrsquos a bit gothic actually.Itrsquos also another example of his originality. And evidence of just what we might losehe was to give it up. BBC Scotland should commission a series.Easter has finished his drink, hersquos ready to get on with his day. He tells me that hersquos still working out how to play the new album live.ldquoI can do accordion versions of stuff, but Irsquom really into dub and Irsquod almost rather just play it back in an interesting way through a load of speakers and hammer it with effects.He has another thought. ldquoWhen Irsquove been playing these versions of songs, Irsquove not actually been playing all the bangers. I think I just need to start to play all the bangers.Sounds like a good plan.Callum Easterrsquos album System is out on Friday via Moshi Moshi Records in association with Lost Map. His album launch gig will be part of Lost Maprsquos Christmas Humbug event at Summerhall in Edinburgh on Friday, December . For tickets, visit lostmapThe Callum Easter TV Special will premiere at Leith Late on Friday and Saturday as part of Leith Late. For more information, visit leithlate

title: introducing-farms-visitors-cant-wait-get-work
story: Farmed by the same family for  generations, even the sheep can trace their heritage back more than  years.But now a quiet revolution in the glen has taken place, the likes of which would have made current farming familyrsquos ancestorsrsquo jaws drop.For coming in their hordes are eager visitors anxious to pay good money to do the kinds of lsquodown on the farmrsquo tasks that in their day were essential ndash and perhaps not particularly loved ndash chores.Itrsquos part of a growing agritourism movement which has seen farmers across the country finding fresh ways to generate income and meet soaring demand from lsquotowniesrsquo anxious to savour a slice of countryside le in the process.For Kay Wilson of Lennox of Lomond, whose family began farming the gentle slopes overlooking Loch Lomond in , demand from the public to get hands on fixing fences, building dykes and helping to round up the sheep on their ,-acre tenanted hill farm, has been unexpectedly high.ldquoWe are finding we have so much demand for farm tours that we sometimes donrsquot have the time to fit it all in, she says.ldquoFolk want that rich experience of being on the farm, they want to really get the feel of a farm. We show them where we are coming from as farmers, and what the land has been used for.ldquoItrsquos about immersing themselves into something that has a deep history. And therersquos a feeling after the pandemic that they want to be outdoors.Visitors happily pay to roll up their sleeves and muck into the kinds of farm tasks that have been a way of le for generations of country folk. Fixing broken fences and learning how to build a drystane dyke are said to be particularly popular.As is the farmrsquos lsquoday in the le of a farmerrsquo all-day experience, which offers the chance to spend the whole day carrying out repairs, carrying out farm jobs and getting close to the farm animals.Indeed, some have been so taken with getting mucky on the farm, they are sharing the experience and buying gt vouchers for their friends to do the same.And itrsquos not just farm tours: recently Kay, , and husband Dougie, , unveiled Bonnie Barns, upmarket glamping retreats designed for couples ndash hot tub included, of course ndash at their Shemore Farm, to complement the existing self-catering business.Le on the farm nowadays, agrees Kay, is about much more than sheep, cattle and crops.Indeed, growing the number and ersity of authentic agritourism experiences in Scotland is among the main ambitions of a new strategy designed to galvanise the countryrsquos valuable agriculture and tourism sectors.Unveiled as part of the Scottish Agritourism conference held at Perth Concert Hall last week, Scottish Agritourism  - The Strategy for Sustainable Growth sets out a shared vision for the sector.Among its aims is to sustainably develop the rural economy, protect family farms for future generations, build consumer awareness and loyalty towards local produce, and celebrate the history and heritage of Scottish farm communities.A key area of focus is on expanding the food and drink experiences farm businesses offer to meet rising demand from consumers for local, seasonal and lsquofarm to forkrsquo produce.The strategy, supported by a staged action plan and spanning public and private sectors, will target both domestic and international tourists.Agritourism, the blending of agriculture and tourism to create days out and holiday experiences on traditional working farms, has become a growing consumer trend, with around  farms, crofts and estates now said to have ersied to attract visitors.Vicki Miller, VisitScotland Director of Marketing and Digital, said: ldquoAs custodians of our countryside, real working farms are a vital part of Scotlandrsquos story.ldquoThe sector is filled with passionate storytellers that can bring to le the unique aspects of our history and heritage, while at the same time educating others about the need to protect and respect our natural assets.At Lennox of Lomond, the farm business which includes Shantron Farm run by Kayrsquos parents, Anne Lennox,  and husband Bobby, , the agritourism is viewed as crucial for the future of the family business.ldquoSuccession is a big thing for us as it is with many other farming families, says Kay. ldquoItrsquos a struggle and there needs to be something financial there to support that succession.ldquoThe farm used to sustain two families, now itrsquos down to one. My parents are in their late s, they are thinking of easing up and as the next generation we want to know therersquos another income stream.Brexitrsquos impact on subsidies has also galvanised farming families to rethink their businesses, along with consumer demands for traceable farm produce, proof of animal welfare and quality.ldquoWersquore not mass production farmers, she adds. ldquoThe sheep we have are direct descendants from the original line that dates from .ldquoPeople want to experience what a farm like ours is like.At Bellevue Farm on the Isle of Arran, Ailsa Currie,  and husband Donald, , have also added farm tours, experience days and farmersrsquo markets to the existing farm cottage self-catering business.ldquoWe opened up the farm for an open day in  and it was a great success, we had people asking when they could come and look around the farm, says Ailsa.ldquoAt first, we just walked people around the farm, let them feed the animals, collect the eggs and told them about our lives, the ups and downs, the changing seasons.ldquoItrsquos grown from there.Therersquos now a purpose-built shed which hosts farm days, tours, and a farmersrsquo market showcasing local produce.ldquoPeople want to know where their food comes from, says Ailsa. ldquoParents think itrsquos good to bring a child to a farm, but often when we explain things like how silage is made and how we use slurry to fertilise the fields, the parents admit they didnrsquot know how much was involved in farming.The loss of farms on the fringes of towns to housing and a growing concern over food miles and processing has fuelled interest, she adds.ldquoI can point to plants and askpeople know what they are and they donrsquot know, and then are amazed when they dig it up and discover itrsquos a carrot.Itrsquos hoped the new strategy will help the agritourism sector double in size with at least % of agritourism businesses offering food and drink by .Helping to launch the strategy, Mairi Gougeon, Cabinet Secretary for Rural Affairs and Islands, said: ldquoBy ersying operations, farmers and crofters generate a stable income and this, in turn, helps to sustain their businesses.ldquoDiversied activity also provides an economic boost to the wider rural community by attracting tourists from urban areas to our countryside.

title: remembrance-sunday-uks-leaders-lay-wreaths-london-edimburgh-queen-absent
story: The Lord Provostrsquos wreath-laying party joined the military parade before the gun was fired, at Edinburgh Castle, on the dot of am to mark the start of the two-minute silence.At .am a second gun ended the silence and a bugler played the last post.Minister of St Giles Cathedral Reverend Calum MacLeod read Binyonrsquos Lines: ldquoThey shall grow not old, as we that are left grow old, Age shall not weary them, nor the years condemn, At the going down of the sun, and in the morning, We will remember them.Lord Provost of the City of Edinburgh Frank Ross laid his wreath at the Stone of Remembrance followed by Ms Sturgeon and Scottish Parliament Presiding Officer Alison Johnstone MSP.First Minister Nicola Sturgeonduring the Remembrance Sunday serviceIn London, members of the royal family and senior politicians have led the nation in honouring the countryrsquos war dead on Remembrance Sunday.Buckingham Palace announced on Sunday morning that the Queen would be absent from the service at the Cenotaph in central London due to having sprained her back.:Queen misses Cenotaph Remembrance Sunday service after spraining her backThe event on Whitehall was given added poignancy by ato pre-pandemic numbers of participating veterans and military, as well as onlookers.The Prince of Wales and Prime Minister were among those laying a wreath at the war memorial for the National Service of Remembrance.Prime Minister Boris Johnson and Labour leader Sir Keir StarmerBoris Johnson, who appeared sombre as he laid a wreath, said it was a moment to ldquocome together to remember those who sacriced everything in service of our country.Only the rustling of leaves and the chirping of birds could be heard as thousands of people held the two-minute silence at am in honour of all those who have lost their lives in conflict.Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer stood beside the Prime Minister while former prime ministers lined up behind Mr Johnson, with John Major, Tony Blair, Gordon Brown, David Cameron and Theresa May all paying their respects.The Duke of Cambridge, Earl of Wessex and Princess Royal also laid wreaths at the memorial.Prince WilliamLooking on from a balcony of the Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office building were the Duchess of Cornwall, Duchess of Cambridge and Countess of Wessex. The Duchess of Cornwall, the Duchess of Cambridge and the Countess of WessexThe palace said the Queen made the decision not to attend ldquowith great regret and is ldquodisappointed to miss it.Service personnel attending the ceremony at the Cenotaph wished the Queen well.Lance Corporal May Percival said: ldquoMy heart goes out to her and her family. I wish her well and the best.RAF Nurse Officer Stephen Andor said: ldquoI wish her well. The Queen has very strong links to the military. She is the head of the armed forces.ldquoI think that every single member of the military wishes her well.The Prince of WalesRoyal Navy Petty Officer Ben Shread, of the Combat Camera team, said: ldquoIt would be nicethe boss was here.ldquoShersquos the head of the armed services. I donrsquot knowshe has ever missed the Remembrance parade before.ldquoSo,there is a reason she is not here it must be a very serious one. We all wish her well.Veterans from the Trucial Oman ScoutsThe Queen has only missed six other Cenotaph ceremonies during her reign: on four occasions when she was on overseas visits to Ghana in , Brazil in , Kenya in  and South Africa in .She was not present during the  and  services as she was pregnant with her two youngest children.

title: green-scotland-cop26-climate-investigation-full
story: Our subscribers will get exclusive accessas we look to answer the pressing questions in Scotlands climate crisis fight.As the COP conference looms on the horizon, we will leave no stone unturned in a bid to stimulate discussion and debate on this crucial topic.Find out more about our exclusive pound for two months offer here.From the hundreds of sites and big-name companies that broke environmental rules, to the most polluted streets in Scotland, readers can expectground-breaking exclusives, in-depth analysis, and interactive content ndash as well as regular live videos, giving you the chance to speak directly with the award-winning reporters behind the stories.Here, you can find every article published in the week-long investigation so far - with this piece being updated daily with new exclusive stories.To make sure you do not miss out on the high-quality insight, join us today by taking out a subscription for just pound for two monthshere.More than  industrial sites across Scotland have been officially damned as ldquounsatisfactory on pollution, according to data from the ScottishEnvironmentProtection Agencyseen by The Ferret.Sepa assessed the environmental performance of two big oilcompanies, ExxonMobil and Ineos, as ldquovery poor in . A Grangemouth chemical plant and a Coupar Angus chicken processor were rated as ldquopoor.Read the full exclusive report here.More than one in ten of Scotlandrsquos fish farms have been rated as ldquounsatisfactory" by the Scottish Governmentrsquos environmental watchdog because of pollution, pesticide and reporting breaches, wecan today reveal.The ScottishEnvironmentProtection Agencyhas assessed over  of some  salmon farms around the coast as either ldquovery poor, ldquopoor or ldquoat risk because they broke, or threatened to break, environmental rules in .The exclusive revelations can be read here in full.WE can today reveal the top sitesacrossScotland that have been officiallydeemed "unsatisfactory" on pollution by Scotlands environmental watchdog.The ScottishEnvironmentProtection Agencydamnedthe performance of more than  sitesincluding Trump Turnberry, Ineos, and Faslane nuclear base.View the full interactive map of sites here.More than , of Scotlands wildle species and natural habitats are in a "poor" condition, and dozens of the nationrsquos protected sites have been damaged byclimate change, we can reveal.Ahead of the COP conference in Glasgow, our joint investigation with The Ferret reveals that  habitats and  species inScotlandare in poor condition. We also found that climate change has impacted  protected sites and  natural features.Read the full exclusive report here.DOZENS of Scotlands protected sites have been damaged byclimate change, we canreveal today.The long term decline of Scotlandrsquos wildle was documented in a report in  called the State of Nature which claimed one in nine species - including kittiwakes and wildcats - was threatened with extinction.View the full map here.MORE than  habitats and  species inScotlandare in "poor" condition, we can reveal.Environmental and wildle groups are calling for urgent action to combat the twinclimate changeand wildle crises and help preserve Scotlandrsquos natural heritage.View the list in full here.Almost a third of Scotlandrsquos streets have higher levels of toxic particle air pollution than they did before the Covid- pandemic, analysis can reveal.#The ldquoappalling findings show the levels of air pollution caused by small particles ndash known as particulate matter and#largely due to traffic pollution ndash increased in  per cent of average readings taken this year, when compared with data from .View the full exclusive report here.Air pollution is to be the subject of a Scotland-wide investigation ndash the first to be carried out by the countrys new environmental watchdog, we can reveal.EnvironmentStandards Scotland , an independent body which came into force on  October to oversee environmental law post-Brexit, confirmed the "intractable issue" which has plagued Scotland for ldquoover a decade would be the focus of its first major piece of work.Read the full story here.The traffic is at a standstill on Atholl Street in the centre of Perth, cars, trucks and buses running their engines as they wait for the lights to change.##For years this city street ndash#with its mixture of shops, cafes and homes ndash#has been amongst Scotlandrsquos most polluted due to levels of particulate matter . Nitrogen dioxide readings are as high as many on the streets of Scotlandrsquos biggest cities. Exposure to high levels of both pollutants has been linked to increased risk ofhealthconditions like asthma, strokes and even dementia.#Read the full case study here.In an open letter to the First Minister, Nicola Sturgeon, published as part of our joint investigation, over  leadinghealthprofessionals ndash including consultants, GPs and medical academics ndash are calling for more action to be taken on air pollution to save lives.Councils must enforce laws, they say, air monitoring should be increased, including outside schools, while the Scottish Government should invest more heavily in active travel, publictransportand green infrastructure.Read the letter in full here.Scotlandrsquos rivers, lochs, canals and burns are in the worst state on record, with more than  damaged by pollution and other problems, according to the latest official analysis.New assessment methods used by the ScottishEnvironmentProtection Agencyhave more than doubled the number of waterways classied as ldquobad between  and . There are ldquosignicant environmental problems caused by a number of pressures, Sepa said.Read the full exclusive report here.SCOTLANDS worst rivers, lochs, canals and burns for pollution have been revealed in new analysis of official watchdog data.Amongst the many rivers rated as either bad or poor by Sepa are some of Scotlandrsquos most well-known. They include long stretches of the Almond, Carron, Dee, Don, Earn, Esk, Kelvin, Lossie, Nairn, Nith, Spey, Tay, Tummel, and Water of Leith.Find how your local river or loch ranks using our interactive toolNearly  sites run by Scottish Water including sewage and wastewater treatment are ldquopoor, ldquovery poor or ldquoat risk, according to Scotlandrsquos environmental watchdog.Almost all these ldquounsatisfactory sites are considered to be among Scotlandrsquos critical national infrastructure ndash operations deemed essential for the state to deliver vital public services.Read the full story here.Today, we reveal the Scottish Government has missed its targets on reducing climate emissions in five of the seven sectors set out in its  plan to tackle climate change.Environmental activists said the missed targets painted a ldquodisappointing picture of widespread failure on emissions reductions. They worry that static or increasing annual emissions in key sectors mean Scotland risks squandering good progress made in other areas.Read the full exclusive report here.The Scottish Government must take ldquoradical action on green job creation and ending fuel povertyit is to achieve a Just Transition to net-zero carbon emissions, trade unions sayThe Scottish low carbon economy provided , jobs in , the most recent data available, a nearly five per cent decrease from . It was also fewer than the , roles provided by the sector in .Read the story in full here.

title: great-western-glasgow-gig-turned-hour-long-soundcheck
story: The Great WesternVarious Venues, Glasgows West End****When does a soundcheck become the actual show That might well have been the question as the sparse, atmospheric, melodic twists of Glasgow-based art-popsters Cloth kicked things off at this Glasgow west end festival.Well, to say it kicked things of, was more theory than actual practice.We waited and waited, with Mogwais Stuart Braithwaite looking onand nearly an hour passed at the positively baroque Maryhill Community Central Hall with a cute bass here, and even some singing there, only to find that it was all still practising.Now that would be fine, but we were treated to over an hour of this and it carried on well after they were due to be off stage for the next band to come on.It was asthere wasnt  of us in the room.So with things at the Glue Factory running to schedule, it was a quick exit to see the Edinburgh-based arty soul punk Callum Easter and, my god, an actual show and goodness gracious, the little tyke is getting his audience to sing along with him.Cue System, a new scuzzy crowd-pleasing indie-pop nugget completed with nananas which the gathering were invited to help with and they duly obliged."Ive got an album oot," he blurts in a weirdly high-pitched east coast-tinged Scots accent. "It is out next Friday. Its gooood."Glasgow-based Taahliah is the first black trans DJ and producer to be nominated and and win in two categories in the Scottish Alternative Music Awards and with just one EP to her name there was curiosity over just what we would be served.It threatened to be Cloth all over again.The roadies brought on the Pioneer decks, only after half an hour to take them off and replace it with a simple Apple Mac. The festival was threatening to turn into one long soundcheck.Much later than scheduled, we were finally at lt off and boy was it worth waiting for.Flanked by two dancers, one of whom had great dficulty keeping a top on, this Sophie-inspired hyperpop inspiration created a set of experimental and disorientating dancefloor majesty that is as original and captivating as you will hear anywhere.The Kilmarnock-born artist comes into her own on the block-rockin Bourgeoisie which makes the walls of this Cavern-esque venue shake.This was, however, more of a DJ set than an actual live show, with Taahliah staring into the Apple Mac screen a lot, while occasionally taking time to throw some shapes with the odd strut.While this festival becomes an impossibilityyou want to cover every venue - with some two miles apart - there is no questioning how eclectic the bands are.I can think of nowhere  where a dancefloor thump would be followed by the delightfully ear-bleeding effect-heavy rf-rock blast that is Londons Part Chimp, once signed to Mogwais Rock Action label.There is then a quick half hour speed-tramp to the QMU to arrive just in the nick of time as London-born and Edinburgh-bred composer, performer and producer, Anna Meredith lands on stage on time.It is perhaps all too perfect.The past Scottish Album of the Year winner and Mercury Prize nominee is gleaming in a black and white striped outfit. Her band are dressed the same. The decor is matching.She is the height of politeness, like a friendly teacher welcoming new children to school for the first time.At one point there is a collective audience shush when the chatter was getting too noisy.Meredith quips: "Oooh it is like we are in the Concert Hall."The music is, however, defiantly dferent. And not just because Meredith throws the kitchen sink at post-electro influenced epics such as the towering Calion, which can come with added tuba and even a cello.She always catches you off guard with a pace switch and a bewildering array of influences from classical to s synthpop to alternative rock.But through it all, it is with the ever so slightly quirkily addictive s synth pop stylings of Inhale Exhale, where she dares to sing, that she brings the house down.And so the festival ends, and the trains, which did not need a soundcheck, left on time.

title: cop26-glasgow-road-openings-full-clyde-expressway-m8-closures-end
story: At am on Monday morningboth the Expresswayand Junction  of the M located at Anderston willre-open and operate as usual now that the climate talks have come to an end.Both roadsusually havethousands of vehicles pass through every day, and have been closed since October  for the international climate summit.The M junction was specically used toescortworldleaders anddelegates travelling through from Edinburgh and outside Glasgow. Joe Bidens -vehicle presidential motorcade was among the long list of envoys that passed through during Cop.The road between Minerva Street andWest Greenhill Place also re-opened at am on Saturday, but themajority of Glasgow roads which have caused signicant travel disruption at the hands of Cop finally open on Monday alongside the Expresswayand Junction .:Glasgow city centre new car free zone announcedThere are also several other roads re-opening in Glasgow onNovember , and other closures will finish throughout the week with the final road re-opening on November .:Commuters in Glasgow urged to ditch cars after COP leads to fall in trafficIt comes as Glasgow City Councilclaim that traffic volumes dropped considerably during theinternationalgathering as roads were closed off and vehicle access to the city centre became limited.They are suggesting that there has been a  per cent reduction of traffic volume in the city during Cop, and are now encouraging commuters to maintain the same travelling practices which lead to the drop.A Glasgow City Council spokesperson said: ldquoDuring the course of the COPclimate changeconference we have seen a  per centreduction in the volume of traffic."It is very encouraging that people visiting Glasgow and people who live and work here followed the pre-conference advice to leave the car at home and use public transport or walk or cycle instead."It also shows the effectiveness of the extensive pre-conference information campaign we carried out and the measures we put in place to manage the traffic.ldquoThis change in behaviour is very welcome and exactly the kind of thing that we would encourage as part of Glasgowrsquos drive to have net zero emissions by .

title: bid to bring winter wonderland to kirkwall next week
story: newsBID to bring Winter Wonderland to Kirkwall next weekNovember ,  at : am vw, px"  Time to get your skates on! Kirkwall BID is bringing an ice rink to town, and much more merriment besides.It’s beginning to look a lot like Christmas everywhere you go in Orkney, as businesses show off their festive fare in the run-up to Yuletide.In Kirkwall, it’s hoped that BID’s Winter Wonderland event will draw more folk to the street, with fun, food, shopping and skating all set to bring an added sparkle to the town centre.“From Thursday, November  to Monday, November , Kirkwall BID will be hosting a free skating rink and other festive attractions right here in the town centre,” said Kirkwall BID chairman, Duncan McLean.“It’s a dark and dreich time of year, so let BID bring some special sparkle, light and joy to the streets with a wonderful array of entertainments.“Next to the ice rink in Bridge Street car park, a rustic Alpine chalet will serve takeaway food and drinks with a skiing-lodge theme: bratwurst, churros, mulledcider and hot chocolate.“It’ll warm the cockles of your heart!”Meanwhile, the Saturday and Sunday are set to bring not only warmth to your heart, but to your stomach too!“Local food and drink producers will showcase their wares at a street market on Saturday, November  and Sunday, November ,” Mr McLean added.“Two special guests will be walking our streets — we can’t reveal their identity yet, but let’s just say they are warm-hearted but chilly sisters, you might say ‘frozen’. Other attractions will be revealed as we get closer to the weekend.“And throughout the town, shops, pubs and cafés will be bursting with festive treats, special offers, and of course Christmas gts and goodies.”Kirkwall BID is keen to emphasise that all activities have been planned and will be carried out with careful attention to the latest COVID advice from NHS Orkney. Everything BID organises over the weekend will take place outdoors, and safe distancing and frequent cleaning will be the order of the day.For more information on Winter Wonderland you can visit the Kirkwall BID Facebook page.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co.
